thread.title: Colorado's use-it or lose-it vacation policy still OK
thread.title_full: Colorado's use-it or lose-it vacation policy still OK - The Denver Post

author: Alicia Wallace
title: Colorado's use-it or lose-it vacation policy still OK
text:
Employers in Colorado don't have to lose their "use it or lose it" vacation policies — but recently some certainly thought they did.
And the state Department of Labor and Employment is getting a lesson in the power of language — even when it's delivered in bullet points.
In September, labor department deputy director Peter Wingate gave a rundown of how the Wage Theft Protection Act changed the labor department to enforcer from mediator in more than 5,000 cases annually.
The meeting at the Denver office of Fisher & Phillips triggered a "legal alert" from the law firm warning that the labor department was leaning toward prohibiting the common policy that earned but untaken vacation is lost at the end of each year.
Soon after, the Mountain States Employers Council fielded a high volume of calls from alarmed members, staff attorney Justin Hocking said.
He sought clarification from the department and received a 13-point document that included the following phrases:
• "Once vacation pay has been earned, it cannot be 'unearned.' Forfeiture clauses are not permitted in vacation agreements."
• "An agreement cannot contain a 'use it or lose it' provision during employment. Once vacation time has been earned, it must be paid out upon separation if it is unused and determinable at that time."
Advertisement Hocking published a memo to members but subsequently reported that Wingate clarified that the official guidance could differ from what had been released informally.
The uncertainty put Hocking and the Mountain States Employers Council in a difficult position.
"We want to make sure that they got the right information and they're making informed decisions and there's no wasted time or resources," he said.
The labor department is expected to issue a clarification Monday, spokeswoman Cher Haavind said.
State officials, meanwhile, say there's no policy being contemplated that would prohibit "use it or lose it" vacation policies.
"Not once was there ever a discussion we were going to implement a policy that was going to overturn decades-old acceptable practices," said Alexandra Hall, acting director of the state labor department.
Where employers have to pay out earned vacation is when an employee leaves the firm, she said. That "upon separation" terminology was not clear in the materials presented at the law firm meeting, she said.
The draft policy was intended for internal processing in a division that primarily deals with cases in which a person no longer is employed at the firm, she said.
"This is one of the many documents we're dealing with creating in this new process," she said. "We're building a car while we're driving it because claims don't stop coming in."
